creator: vicentesalvador@netscape.net
text:
We will like to implement a single session across all Contexts. We've tested we
can do this with a Manager but every new Context we must change the server.xml
file to add this context with the Manager.

Allowing a Manager configuration inside the DefaultContext will allow us to
implement this feature accross all Context wherever they are.

Sorry for the spam I've included this text on another bug...

You should note that sharing a single session across web applications violates
the servlet specification.  It is also going to cause you grief if you are
loading session attribute classes from within one of the webapps and trying to
access it from another -- the underlying classes will not be visible because
each web app has their own class loader.

If you care only about having a user sign on once to a set of applications,
check out the "Single Sign On" facility.  The user will still have a session per
web app, but they will only be challenged for logging on one time, rather than
once per app.  See the configuration information on the <Host> element for
details.
creator: craig.mcclanahan@sun.com
vanza@rededc.com.br
text:
Anybody looking into this bug? As far as I've tested, it's not resolved...

Allowing a Manager inside a DefaultContext makes it easy, for example, to
disable session persistence for a whole set of web applications.

In a case like we have here (three tomcat servers, lots and lots of applications
running for development), having a Manager inside a DefaultContext would make it
really easy to disable session persistence.
